texts.shortText: Tiny white isopod most easily recognised by its unusual habit of boring into wood. Antennae very short, abdominal segments not fused, segment 5 with a V-shaped dorsal ridge. Pleotelson large and rounded, with 3 small dorsal knobs arranged to form a triangle; uropods tiny, outer branch bent outwards.

Global: Cosmopolitan. Has been very widely distributed in warmer waters around the world by wooden ships, such that its area of origin is now obscure.

Local/Regional: Only recently (2008) detected in Table Bay and known only from that site, although must certainly have been present there for many decades and almost certainly also occurs in other harbours and marinas in the region.

Bores into the wood of wooden vessels and particularly pier pilings etc. Heavily infected pilings have a characteristic hourglass shape in which the lower intertidal section has been severely eroded away. A single pair normally occupy each tunnel, the female occurring close to the opening. Burrows tend to follow the grain of the wood and are initially confined to the surface layers, but as these crumble away damage extends deeper.

Like all isopods the eggs are released into a marsupium between the walking legs of the female, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released. Due to the small size of adults brood size is unusually small at 5–15 eggs per female.

A second cosmopolitan and introduced species, L. quadripunctata, also occurs in harbours from Cape Town to Port Elizabeth, as well as in natural habitats such as kelp holdfasts. As the name suggests it has 4 rather than 3 small knobs on the pleotelson, these being arranged in a square.

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 83, L. quadripunctata).

Picker, M & Griffiths, CL (2011). Alien and invasive animals – a South African perspective. Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 165).
